words.def: See H-closed
words.name: Absolutely closed

words.def:
See 
  
    
      
        
          T
          
            1
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle T_{1}}
  
.
words.name: Accessible

words.def: See limit point.
words.name: Accumulation point

words.def: The topology of a space X is an Alexandrov topology (or is finitely generated) if arbitrary intersections of open sets in X are open, or equivalently, if arbitrary unions of closed sets are closed, or, again equivalently, if the open sets are the upper sets of a poset.[1]
words.name: Alexandrov topology

words.def: A space is almost discrete if every open set is closed (hence clopen). The almost discrete spaces are precisely the finitely generated zero-dimensional spaces.
words.name: Almost discrete

words.def: An approach space is a generalization of metric space based on point-to-set distances, instead of point-to-point.
words.name: Approach space

words.def:
This has two distinct common meanings:

A space is a Baire space if the intersection of any countable collection of dense open sets is dense; see Baire space.
Baire space is the set of all functions from the natural numbers to the natural numbers, with the topology of pointwise convergence; see Baire space (set theory).
words.name: Baire space
Base

words.def: See Base.
words.name: Basis
Borel algebra

words.def: A Borel set is an element of a Borel algebra.
words.name: Borel set

words.def:
The boundary (or frontier) of a set is the set's closure minus its interior. Equivalently, the boundary of a set is the intersection of its closure with the closure of its complement. Boundary of a set 
  
    
      
        A
      
    
    {\displaystyle A}
  
 is denoted by 
  
    
      
        ∂
        A
      
    
    {\displaystyle \partial A}
  
 or 
  
    
      
        b
        d
      
    
    {\displaystyle bd}
  
 
  
    
      
        A
      
    
    {\displaystyle A}
  
.
words.name: Boundary

words.def: A set in a metric space is bounded if it has finite diameter. Equivalently, a set is bounded if it is contained in some open ball of finite radius. A function taking values in a metric space is bounded if its image is a bounded set.
words.name: Bounded

words.def: The category Top has topological spaces as objects and continuous maps as morphisms.
words.name: Category of topological spaces

words.def: A sequence {xn} in a metric space (M, d) is a Cauchy sequence if, for every positive real number r, there is an integer N such that for all integers m, n > N, we have d(xm, xn) < r.
words.name: Cauchy sequence

words.def: A set is clopen if it is both open and closed.
words.name: Clopen set

words.def: If (M, d) is a metric space, a closed ball is a set of the form D(x; r) := {y in M : d(x, y) ≤ r}, where x is in M and r is a positive real number, the radius of the ball. A closed ball of radius r is a closed r-ball. Every closed ball is a closed set in the topology induced on M by d. Note that the closed ball D(x; r) might not be equal to the closure of the open ball B(x; r).
words.name: Closed ball

words.def: A set is closed if its complement is a member of the topology.
words.name: Closed set

words.def: A function from one space to another is closed if the image of every closed set is closed.
words.name: Closed function

words.def: The closure of a set is the smallest closed set containing the original set. It is equal to the intersection of all closed sets which contain it. An element of the closure of a set S is a point of closure of S.
words.name: Closure

words.def: See Kuratowski closure axioms.
words.name: Closure operator

words.def: If X is a set, and if T1 and T2 are topologies on X, then T1 is coarser (or smaller, weaker) than T2 if T1 is contained in T2. Beware, some authors, especially analysts, use the term stronger.
words.name: Coarser topology

words.def: A subset A of a space X is comeagre (comeager) if its complement X\A is meagre. Also called residual.
words.name: Comeagre

words.def: A space is compact if every open cover has a finite subcover. Every compact space is Lindelöf and paracompact. Therefore, every compact Hausdorff space is normal. See also quasicompact.
words.name: Compact

words.def: The compact-open topology on the set C(X, Y) of all continuous maps between two spaces X and Y is defined as follows: given a compact subset K of X and an open subset U of Y, let V(K, U) denote the set of all maps f in C(X, Y) such that f(K) is contained in U. Then the collection of all such V(K, U) is a subbase for the compact-open topology.
words.name: Compact-open topology

words.def: A metric space is complete if every Cauchy sequence converges.
words.name: Complete

words.def: See complete space.
words.name: Completely metrizable/completely metrisable

words.def: A space is completely normal if any two separated sets have disjoint neighbourhoods.
words.name: Completely normal

words.def: A completely normal Hausdorff space (or T5 space) is a completely normal T1 space. (A completely normal space is Hausdorff if and only if it is T1, so the terminology is consistent.) Every completely normal Hausdorff space is normal Hausdorff.
words.name: Completely normal Hausdorff

words.def: A space is completely regular if, whenever C is a closed set and x is a point not in C, then C and {x} are functionally separated.
words.name: Completely regular

words.def: See Tychonoff.
words.name: Completely T3

words.def: See Connected component/Path-connected component.
words.name: Component

words.def: A space is connected if it is not the union of a pair of disjoint nonempty open sets. Equivalently, a space is connected if the only clopen sets are the whole space and the empty set.
words.name: Connected

words.def: A connected component of a space is a maximal nonempty connected subspace. Each connected component is closed, and the set of connected components of a space is a partition of that space.
words.name: Connected component

words.def: A function from one space to another is continuous if the preimage of every open set is open.
words.name: Continuous

words.def: A space is called a continuum if it a compact, connected Hausdorff space.
words.name: Continuum

words.def: A space X is contractible if the identity map on X is homotopic to a constant map. Every contractible space is simply connected.
words.name: Contractible

words.def: If {Xi} is a collection of spaces and X is the (set-theoretic) disjoint union of {Xi}, then the coproduct topology (or disjoint union topology, topological sum of the Xi) on X is the finest topology for which all the injection maps are continuous.
words.name: Coproduct topology

words.def: A continuous image of some separable metric space.[2]
words.name: Cosmic space

words.def: A space X satisfies the countable chain condition if every family of non-empty, pairswise disjoint open sets is countable.
words.name: Countable chain condition

words.def: A space is countably compact if every countable open cover has a finite subcover. Every countably compact space is pseudocompact and weakly countably compact.
words.name: Countably compact

words.def: A collection of subsets of a space X is countably locally finite (or σ-locally finite) if it is the union of a countable collection of locally finite collections of subsets of X.
words.name: Countably locally finite

words.def: A collection of subsets of a space is a cover (or covering) of that space if the union of the collection is the whole space.
words.name: Cover

words.def: See Cover.
words.name: Covering

words.def: If X is a connected space with more than one point, then a point x of X is a cut point if the subspace X − {x} is disconnected.
words.name: Cut point

words.def: A set is dense if it has nonempty intersection with every nonempty open set. Equivalently, a set is dense if its closure is the whole space.
words.name: Dense set

words.def: A set is dense-in-itself if it has no isolated point.
words.name: Dense-in-itself set

words.def: the minimal cardinality of a dense subset of a topological space. A set of density ℵ0 is a separable space.[3]
words.name: Density

words.def: If X is a space and S is a subset of X, the derived set of S in X is the set of limit points of S in X.
words.name: Derived set

words.def: A topological space with a development.[4]
words.name: Developable space

words.def: A countable collection of open covers of a topological space, such that for any closed set C and any point p in its complement there exists a cover in the collection such that every neighbourhood of p in the cover is disjoint from C.[4]
words.name: Development

words.def: If (M, d) is a metric space and S is a subset of M, the diameter of S is the supremum of the distances d(x, y), where x and y range over S.
words.name: Diameter

words.def: The discrete metric on a set X is the function d : X × X  →  R such that for all x, y in X, d(x, x) = 0 and d(x, y) = 1 if x ≠ y. The discrete metric induces the discrete topology on X.
words.name: Discrete metric

words.def: A space X is discrete if every subset of X is open. We say that X carries the discrete topology.[5]
words.name: Discrete space

words.def: See discrete space.
words.name: Discrete topology

words.def: See Coproduct topology.
words.name: Disjoint union topology

words.def: If X is a connected space with more than one point, then a point x of X is a dispersion point if the subspace X − {x} is hereditarily disconnected (its only connected components are the one-point sets).
words.name: Dispersion point

words.def: See metric space.
words.name: Distance

words.def: See Uniform space.
words.name: Entourage

words.def: The exterior of a set is the interior of its complement.
words.name: Exterior

words.def: An Fσ set is a countable union of closed sets.[6]
words.name: Fσ set

words.def:
A filter on a space X is a nonempty family F of subsets of X such that the following conditions hold:

The empty set is not in F.
The intersection of any finite number of elements of F is again in F.
If A is in F and if B contains A, then B is in F.
words.name: Filter

words.def:
On a set X with respect to a family of functions into 
  
    
      
        X
      
    
    {\displaystyle X}
  
, is the finest topology on X which makes those functions continuous.[7]
words.name: Final topology

words.def:
On Euclidean space 
  
    
      
        
          
            R
          
          
            n
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}}
  
, the coarsest topology making all subharmonic functions (equivalently all superharmonic functions) continuous.[8]
words.name: Fine topology (potential theory)

words.def: If X is a set, and if T1 and T2 are topologies on X, then T2 is finer (or larger, stronger) than T1 if T2 contains T1. Beware, some authors, especially analysts, use the term weaker.
words.name: Finer topology

words.def: See Alexandrov topology.
words.name: Finitely generated

words.def: See Meagre.
words.name: First category

words.def: A space is first-countable if every point has a countable local base.
words.name: First-countable

words.def: See T1.
words.name: Fréchet

words.def: See Boundary.
words.name: Frontier

words.def: A compact subset K of the complex plane is called full if its complement is connected. For example, the closed unit disk is full, while the unit circle is not.
words.name: Full set

words.def: Two sets A and B in a space X are functionally separated if there is a continuous map f: X  →  [0, 1] such that f(A) = 0 and f(B) = 1.
words.name: Functionally separated

words.def: A Gδ set or inner limiting set is a countable intersection of open sets.[6]
words.name: Gδ set

words.def: A space in which every closed set is a Gδ set.[6]
words.name: Gδ space

words.def: A generic point for a closed set is a point for which the closed set is the closure of the singleton set containing that point.[9]
words.name: Generic point

words.def: A Hausdorff space (or T2 space) is one in which every two distinct points have disjoint neighbourhoods. Every Hausdorff space is T1.
words.name: Hausdorff

words.def: A space is H-closed, or Hausdorff closed or absolutely closed, if it is closed in every Hausdorff space containing it.
words.name: H-closed

words.def: A space is hereditarily P for some property P if every subspace is also P.
words.name: Hereditarily P

words.def: A property of spaces is said to be hereditary if whenever a space has that property, then so does every subspace of it.[10] For example, second-countability is a hereditary property.
words.name: Hereditary

words.def: If X and Y are spaces, a homeomorphism from X to Y is a bijective function f : X → Y such that f and f−1 are continuous. The spaces X and Y are then said to be homeomorphic. From the standpoint of topology, homeomorphic spaces are identical.
words.name: Homeomorphism

words.def: A space X is homogeneous if, for every x and y in X, there is a homeomorphism f : X  →  X such that f(x) = y. Intuitively, the space looks the same at every point. Every topological group is homogeneous.
words.name: Homogeneous

words.def: Two continuous maps f, g : X  →  Y are homotopic (in Y) if there is a continuous map H : X × [0, 1]  →  Y such that H(x, 0) = f(x) and H(x, 1) = g(x) for all x in X. Here, X × [0, 1] is given the product topology. The function H is called a homotopy (in Y) between f and g.
words.name: Homotopic maps

words.def: See Homotopic maps.
words.name: Homotopy

words.def: A space is hyper-connected if no two non-empty open sets are disjoint[11] Every hyper-connected space is connected.[11]
words.name: Hyper-connected

words.def: See Quotient map.
words.name: Identification map

words.def: See Quotient space.
words.name: Identification space

words.def: See Trivial topology.
words.name: Indiscrete space

words.def: See Hilbert manifold and Q-manifolds, i.e. (generalized) manifolds modelled on the Hilbert space and on the Hilbert cube respectively.
words.name: Infinite-dimensional topology

words.def: A Gδ set.[6]
words.name: Inner limiting set

words.def: The interior of a set is the largest open set contained in the original set. It is equal to the union of all open sets contained in it. An element of the interior of a set S is an interior point of S.
words.name: Interior

words.def: See Interior.
words.name: Interior point

words.def: A point x is an isolated point if the singleton {x} is open. More generally, if S is a subset of a space X, and if x is a point of S, then x is an isolated point of S if {x} is open in the subspace topology on S.
words.name: Isolated point

words.def: If M1 and M2 are metric spaces, an isometric isomorphism from M1 to M2 is a bijective isometry f : M1  →  M2. The metric spaces are then said to be isometrically isomorphic. From the standpoint of metric space theory, isometrically isomorphic spaces are identical.
words.name: Isometric isomorphism

words.def: If (M1, d1) and (M2, d2) are metric spaces, an isometry from M1 to M2 is a function f : M1  →  M2 such that d2(f(x), f(y)) = d1(x, y) for all x, y in M1. Every isometry is injective, although not every isometry is surjective.
words.name: Isometry

words.def: See T0.
words.name: Kolmogorov axiom

words.def:
The Kuratowski closure axioms is a set of axioms satisfied by the function which takes each subset of X to its closure:

Isotonicity: Every set is contained in its closure.
Idempotence: The closure of the closure of a set is equal to the closure of that set.
Preservation of binary unions: The closure of the union of two sets is the union of their closures.
Preservation of nullary unions: The closure of the empty set is empty.
words.name: Kuratowski closure axioms
Kolmogorov topology

words.def: An L-space is a hereditarily Lindelöf space which is not hereditarily separable. A Suslin line would be an L-space.[12]
words.name: L-space

words.def: See Finer topology.
words.name: Larger topology

words.def: A point x in a space X is a limit point of a subset S if every open set containing x also contains a point of S other than x itself. This is equivalent to requiring that every neighbourhood of x contains a point of S other than x itself.
words.name: Limit point

words.def: See Weakly countably compact.
words.name: Limit point compact

words.def: A space is Lindelöf if every open cover has a countable subcover.
words.name: Lindelöf

words.def: A set B of neighbourhoods of a point x of a space X is a local base (or local basis, neighbourhood base, neighbourhood basis) at x if every neighbourhood of x contains some member of B.
words.name: Local base

words.def: See Local base.
words.name: Local basis

words.def: There are two definitions for a space to be "locally (P)" where (P) is a topological or set-theoretic property: that each point has a neighbourhood with property (P), or that every point has a neighourbood base for which each member has property (P). The first definition is usually taken for locally compact, countably compact, metrisable, separable, countable; the second for locally connected.[13]
words.name: Locally (P) space

words.def: A subset of a topological space that is the intersection of an open and a closed subset. Equivalently, it is a relatively open subset of its closure.
words.name: Locally closed subset

words.def: A space is locally compact if every point has a compact neighbourhood: the alternative definition that each point has a local base consisting of compact neighbourhoods is sometimes used: these are equivalent for Hausdorff spaces.[13] Every locally compact Hausdorff space is Tychonoff.
words.name: Locally compact

words.def: A space is locally connected if every point has a local base consisting of connected neighbourhoods.[13]
words.name: Locally connected

words.def: A collection of subsets of a space is locally finite if every point has a neighbourhood which has nonempty intersection with only finitely many of the subsets. See also countably locally finite, point finite.
words.name: Locally finite

words.def: A space is locally metrizable if every point has a metrizable neighbourhood.[13]
words.name: Locally metrizable/Locally metrisable

words.def: A space is locally path-connected if every point has a local base consisting of path-connected neighbourhoods.[13] A locally path-connected space is connected if and only if it is path-connected.
words.name: Locally path-connected

words.def: A space is locally simply connected if every point has a local base consisting of simply connected neighbourhoods.
words.name: Locally simply connected

words.def: If x is a point in a space X, a loop at x in X (or a loop in X with basepoint x) is a path f in X, such that f(0) = f(1) = x. Equivalently, a loop in X is a continuous map from the unit circle S1 into X.
words.name: Loop

words.def: If X is a space and A is a subset of X, then A is meagre in X (or of first category in X) if it is the countable union of nowhere dense sets. If A is not meagre in X, A is of second category in X.[14]
words.name: Meagre

words.def: A space is metacompact if every open cover has a point finite open refinement.
words.name: Metacompact

words.def: See Metric space.
words.name: Metric

words.def: A metric invariant is a property which is preserved under isometric isomorphism.
words.name: Metric invariant

words.def: If X and Y are metric spaces with metrics dX and dY respectively, then a metric map is a function f from X to Y, such that for any points x and y in X, dY(f(x), f(y)) ≤ dX(x, y). A metric map is strictly metric if the above inequality is strict for all x and y in X.
words.name: Metric map

words.def:
A metric space (M, d) is a set M equipped with a function d : M × M → R satisfying the following axioms for all x, y, and z in M:

d(x, y) ≥ 0
d(x, x) = 0
if   d(x, y) = 0   then   x = y     (identity of indiscernibles)
d(x, y) = d(y, x)     (symmetry)
d(x, z) ≤ d(x, y) + d(y, z)     (triangle inequality)
words.name: Metric space

words.def: A space is metrizable if it is homeomorphic to a metric space. Every metrizable space is Hausdorff and paracompact (and hence normal and Tychonoff). Every metrizable space is first-countable.
words.name: Metrizable/Metrisable

words.def: Every non-empty ultra-connected compact space X has a largest proper open subset; this subset is called a monolith.
words.name: Monolith

words.def: A Moore space is a developable regular Hausdorff space.[4]
words.name: Moore space

words.def: A neighbourhood of a point x is a set containing an open set which in turn contains the point x. More generally, a neighbourhood of a set S is a set containing an open set which in turn contains the set S. A neighbourhood of a point x is thus a neighbourhood of the singleton set {x}. (Note that under this definition, the neighbourhood itself need not be open. Many authors require that neighbourhoods be open; be careful to note conventions.)
words.name: Neighbourhood/Neighborhood

words.def: See Local base.
words.name: Neighbourhood base/basis

words.def: A neighbourhood system at a point x in a space is the collection of all neighbourhoods of x.
words.name: Neighbourhood system for a point x

words.def: A net in a space X is a map from a directed set A to X. A net from A to X is usually denoted (xα), where α is an index variable ranging over A. Every sequence is a net, taking A to be the directed set of natural numbers with the usual ordering.
words.name: Net

words.def: A space is normal if any two disjoint closed sets have disjoint neighbourhoods.[6] Every normal space admits a partition of unity.
words.name: Normal

words.def: A normal Hausdorff space (or T4 space) is a normal T1 space. (A normal space is Hausdorff if and only if it is T1, so the terminology is consistent.) Every normal Hausdorff space is Tychonoff.
words.name: Normal Hausdorff

words.def: A nowhere dense set is a set whose closure has empty interior.
words.name: Nowhere dense

words.def: An open cover is a cover consisting of open sets.[4]
words.name: Open cover

words.def: If (M, d) is a metric space, an open ball is a set of the form B(x; r) := {y in M : d(x, y) < r}, where x is in M and r is a positive real number, the radius of the ball. An open ball of radius r is an open r-ball. Every open ball is an open set in the topology on M induced by d.
words.name: Open ball

words.def: See open property.
words.name: Open condition

words.def: An open set is a member of the topology.
words.name: Open set

words.def: A function from one space to another is open if the image of every open set is open.
words.name: Open function

words.def: A property of points in a topological space is said to be "open" if those points which possess it form an open set. Such conditions often take a common form, and that form can be said to be an open condition; for example, in metric spaces, one defines an open ball as above, and says that "strict inequality is an open condition".
words.name: Open property

words.def: A space is paracompact if every open cover has a locally finite open refinement. Paracompact implies metacompact.[15] Paracompact Hausdorff spaces are normal.[16]
words.name: Paracompact

words.def: A partition of unity of a space X is a set of continuous functions from X to [0, 1] such that any point has a neighbourhood where all but a finite number of the functions are identically zero, and the sum of all the functions on the entire space is identically 1.
words.name: Partition of unity

words.def: A path in a space X is a continuous map f from the closed unit interval [0, 1] into X. The point f(0) is the initial point of f; the point f(1) is the terminal point of f.[11]
words.name: Path

words.def: A space X is path-connected if, for every two points x, y in X, there is a path f from x to y, i.e., a path with initial point f(0) = x and terminal point f(1) = y. Every path-connected space is connected.[11]
words.name: Path-connected

words.def: A path-connected component of a space is a maximal nonempty path-connected subspace. The set of path-connected components of a space is a partition of that space, which is finer than the partition into connected components.[11] The set of path-connected components of a space X is denoted π0(X).
words.name: Path-connected component

words.def: a normal space which is also a Gδ.[6]
words.name: Perfectly normal

words.def: A collection B of nonempty open sets is a π-base for a topology τ if every nonempty open set in τ includes a set from B.[17]
words.name: π-base

words.def: A point is an element of a topological space. More generally, a point is an element of any set with an underlying topological structure; e.g. an element of a metric space or a topological group is also a "point".
words.name: Point

words.def: See Closure.
words.name: Point of closure

words.def: A space is Polish if it is separable and completely metrizable, i.e. if it is homeomorphic to a separable and complete metric space.
words.name: Polish

words.def: A space is polyadic if it is the continuous image of the power of a one-point compactification of a locally compact, non-compact Hausdorff space.
words.name: Polyadic

words.def: A point of a topological space is a P-point if its filter of neighbourhoods is closed under countable intersections.
words.name: P-point

words.def: See Relatively compact.
words.name: Pre-compact

words.def: The prodiscrete topology on a product AG is the product topology when each factor A is given the discrete topology.[18]
words.name: Prodiscrete topology

words.def: If {Xi} is a collection of spaces and X is the (set-theoretic) product of {Xi}, then the product topology on X is the coarsest topology for which all the projection maps are continuous.
words.name: Product topology

words.def: A continuous function f from a space X to a space Y is proper if f−1(C) is a compact set in X for any compact subspace C of Y.
words.name: Proper function/mapping

words.def: A proximity space (X, δ) is a set X equipped with a binary relation δ between subsets of X satisfying the following properties:
words.name: Proximity space

words.def: A space is pseudocompact if every real-valued continuous function on the space is bounded.
words.name: Pseudocompact

words.def: See Pseudometric space.
words.name: Pseudometric

words.def: A pseudometric space (M, d) is a set M equipped with a function d : M × M → R satisfying all the conditions of a metric space, except possibly the identity of indiscernibles. That is, points in a pseudometric space may be "infinitely close" without being identical. The function d is a pseudometric on M. Every metric is a pseudometric.
words.name: Pseudometric space

words.def: A punctured neighbourhood of a point x is a neighbourhood of x, minus {x}. For instance, the interval (−1, 1) = {y : −1 < y < 1} is a neighbourhood of x = 0 in the real line, so the set (−1, 0) ∪ (0, 1) = (−1, 1) − {0} is a punctured neighbourhood of 0.
words.name: Punctured neighbourhood/Punctured neighborhood

words.def: See compact. Some authors define "compact" to include the Hausdorff separation axiom, and they use the term quasicompact to mean what we call in this glossary simply "compact" (without the Hausdorff axiom). This convention is most commonly found in French, and branches of mathematics heavily influenced by the French.
words.name: Quasicompact

words.def:
If X and Y are spaces, and if f is a surjection from X to Y, then f is a quotient map (or identification map) if, for every subset U of Y, U is open in Y if and only if f -1(U) is open in X. In other words, Y has the f-strong topology. Equivalently, 
  
    
      
        f
      
    
    {\displaystyle f}
  
 is a quotient map if and only if it is the transfinite composition of maps 
  
    
      
        X
        →
        X
        
          /
        
        Z
      
    
    {\displaystyle X\rightarrow X/Z}
  
, where 
  
    
      
        Z
        ⊂
        X
      
    
    {\displaystyle Z\subset X}
  
 is a subset. Note that this doesn't imply that f is an open function.
words.name: Quotient map

words.def: If X is a space, Y is a set, and f : X → Y is any surjective function, then the quotient topology on Y induced by f is the finest topology for which f is continuous. The space X is a quotient space or identification space. By definition, f is a quotient map. The most common example of this is to consider an equivalence relation on X, with Y the set of equivalence classes and f the natural projection map. This construction is dual to the construction of the subspace topology.
words.name: Quotient space

words.def: A cover K is a refinement of a cover L if every member of K is a subset of some member of L.
words.name: Refinement

words.def: A space is regular if, whenever C is a closed set and x is a point not in C, then C and x have disjoint neighbourhoods.
words.name: Regular

words.def: A space is regular Hausdorff (or T3) if it is a regular T0 space. (A regular space is Hausdorff if and only if it is T0, so the terminology is consistent.)
words.name: Regular Hausdorff

words.def: A subset of a space X is regular open if it equals the interior of its closure; dually, a regular closed set is equal to the closure of its interior.[19] An example of a non-regular open set is the set U = (0,1) ∪ (1,2) in R with its normal topology, since 1 is in the interior of the closure of U, but not in U. The regular open subsets of a space form a complete Boolean algebra.[19]
words.name: Regular open

words.def: A subset Y of a space X is relatively compact in X if the closure of Y in X is compact.
words.name: Relatively compact

words.def: If X is a space and A is a subset of X, then A is residual in X if the complement of A is meagre in X. Also called comeagre or comeager.
words.name: Residual

words.def: A topological space is called resolvable if it is expressible as the union of two disjoint dense subsets.
words.name: Resolvable

words.def: A space is rim-compact if it has a base of open sets whose boundaries are compact.
words.name: Rim-compact

words.def: An S-space is a hereditarily separable space which is not hereditarily Lindelöf.[12]
words.name: S-space

words.def: A space X is scattered if every nonempty subset A of X contains a point isolated in A.
words.name: Scattered

words.def: The Scott topology on a poset is that in which the open sets are those Upper sets inaccessible by directed joins.[20]
words.name: Scott

words.def: See Meagre.
words.name: Second category

words.def: A space is second-countable or perfectly separable if it has a countable base for its topology.[6] Every second-countable space is first-countable, separable, and Lindelöf.
words.name: Second-countable

words.def: A space X is semilocally simply connected if, for every point x in X, there is a neighbourhood U of x such that every loop at x in U is homotopic in X to the constant loop x. Every simply connected space and every locally simply connected space is semilocally simply connected. (Compare with locally simply connected; here, the homotopy is allowed to live in X, whereas in the definition of locally simply connected, the homotopy must live in U.)
words.name: Semilocally simply connected

words.def: A space is semiregular if the regular open sets form a base.
words.name: Semiregular

words.def: A space is separable if it has a countable dense subset.[6][14]
words.name: Separable

words.def: Two sets A and B are separated if each is disjoint from the other's closure.
words.name: Separated

words.def: A space is sequentially compact if every sequence has a convergent subsequence. Every sequentially compact space is countably compact, and every first-countable, countably compact space is sequentially compact.
words.name: Sequentially compact

words.def: See metric map
words.name: Short map

words.def: A space is simply connected if it is path-connected and every loop is homotopic to a constant map.
words.name: Simply connected

words.def: See Coarser topology.
words.name: Smaller topology

words.def: In a sober space, every irreducible closed subset is the closure of exactly one point: that is, has a unique generic point.[21]
words.name: Sober

words.def: The star of a point in a given cover of a topological space is the union of all the sets in the cover that contain the point. See star refinement.
words.name: Star

words.def:
Let 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        X
        →
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle f\colon X\rightarrow Y}
  
 be a map of topological spaces. We say that 
  
    
      
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle Y}
  
 has the 
  
    
      
        f
      
    
    {\displaystyle f}
  
-strong topology if, for every subset 
  
    
      
        U
        ⊂
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle U\subset Y}
  
, one has that 
  
    
      
        U
      
    
    {\displaystyle U}
  
 is open in 
  
    
      
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle Y}
  
 if and only if 
  
    
      
        
          f
          
            −
            1
          
        
        (
        U
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle f^{-1}(U)}
  
 is open in 
  
    
      
        X
      
    
    {\displaystyle X}
See Finer topology. Beware, some authors, especially analysts, use the term weaker topology.
words.name: Stronger topology

words.def: A collection of open sets is a subbase (or subbasis) for a topology if every non-empty proper open set in the topology is a union of finite intersections of sets in the subbase. If B is any collection of subsets of a set X, the topology on X generated by B is the smallest topology containing B; this topology consists of the empty set, X and all unions of finite intersections of elements of B.
words.name: Subbase

words.def: See Subbase.
words.name: Subbasis

words.def: A cover K is a subcover (or subcovering) of a cover L if every member of K is a member of L.
words.name: Subcover

words.def: See Subcover.
words.name: Subcovering

words.def: A topological space is said to be submaximal if every subset of it is locally closed, that is, every subset is the intersection of an open set and a closed set.
words.name: Submaximal space

words.def: If T is a topology on a space X, and if A is a subset of X, then the subspace topology on A induced by T consists of all intersections of open sets in T with A. This construction is dual to the construction of the quotient topology.
words.name: Subspace

words.def: A space is T0 (or Kolmogorov) if for every pair of distinct points x and y in the space, either there is an open set containing x but not y, or there is an open set containing y but not x.
words.name: T0

words.def: A space is T1 (or Fréchet or accessible) if for every pair of distinct points x and y in the space, there is an open set containing x but not y. (Compare with T0; here, we are allowed to specify which point will be contained in the open set.) Equivalently, a space is T1 if all its singletons are closed. Every T1 space is T0.
words.name: T1

words.def: See Hausdorff space.
words.name: T2

words.def: See Regular Hausdorff.
words.name: T3

words.def: See Tychonoff space.
words.name: T3½

words.def: See Normal Hausdorff.
words.name: T4

words.def: See Completely normal Hausdorff.
words.name: T5

words.def: See Category of topological spaces.
words.name: Top

words.def: A topological invariant is a property which is preserved under homeomorphism. For example, compactness and connectedness are topological properties, whereas boundedness and completeness are not. Algebraic topology is the study of topologically invariant abstract algebra constructions on topological spaces.
words.name: Topological invariant

words.def: A topological space (X, T) is a set X equipped with a collection T of subsets of X satisfying the following axioms:
words.name: Topological space

words.def: See Coproduct topology.
words.name: Topological sum

words.def: Completely metrizable spaces (i. e. topological spaces homeomorphic to complete metric spaces) are often called topologically complete; sometimes the term is also used for Čech-complete spaces or completely uniformizable spaces.
words.name: Topologically complete

words.def: See Topological space.
words.name: Topology

words.def: A metric space M is totally bounded if, for every r > 0, there exist a finite cover of M by open balls of radius r. A metric space is compact if and only if it is complete and totally bounded.
words.name: Totally bounded

words.def: A space is totally disconnected if it has no connected subset with more than one point.
words.name: Totally disconnected

words.def: The trivial topology (or indiscrete topology) on a set X consists of precisely the empty set and the entire space X.
words.name: Trivial topology

words.def: A Tychonoff space (or completely regular Hausdorff space, completely T3 space, T3.5 space) is a completely regular T0 space. (A completely regular space is Hausdorff if and only if it is T0, so the terminology is consistent.) Every Tychonoff space is regular Hausdorff.
words.name: Tychonoff

words.def: A space is ultra-connected if no two non-empty closed sets are disjoint.[11] Every ultra-connected space is path-connected.
words.name: Ultra-connected

words.def: A metric is an ultrametric if it satisfies the following stronger version of the triangle inequality: for all x, y, z in M, d(x, z) ≤ max(d(x, y), d(y, z)).
words.name: Ultrametric

words.def: If X and Y are uniform spaces, a uniform isomorphism from X to Y is a bijective function f : X → Y such that f and f−1 are uniformly continuous. The spaces are then said to be uniformly isomorphic and share the same uniform properties.
words.name: Uniform isomorphism

words.def: A space is uniformizable if it is homeomorphic to a uniform space.
words.name: Uniformizable/Uniformisable

words.def: A uniform space is a set U equipped with a nonempty collection Φ of subsets of the Cartesian product X × X satisfying the following axioms:
words.name: Uniform space

words.def: See Uniform space.
words.name: Uniform structure

words.def: The weak topology on a set, with respect to a collection of functions from that set into topological spaces, is the coarsest topology on the set which makes all the functions continuous.
words.name: Weak topology

words.def: See Coarser topology. Beware, some authors, especially analysts, use the term stronger topology.
words.name: Weaker topology

words.def: A space is weakly countably compact (or limit point compact) if every infinite subset has a limit point.
words.name: Weakly countably compact

words.def: A property of spaces is said to be weakly hereditary if whenever a space has that property, then so does every closed subspace of it. For example, compactness and the Lindelöf property are both weakly hereditary properties, although neither is hereditary.
words.name: Weakly hereditary

words.def: The weight of a space X is the smallest cardinal number κ such that X has a base of cardinal κ. (Note that such a cardinal number exists, because the entire topology forms a base, and because the class of cardinal numbers is well-ordered.)
words.name: Weight

words.def: See Ultra-connected. (Some authors use this term strictly for ultra-connected compact spaces.)
words.name: Well-connected

words.def: A space is zero-dimensional if it has a base of clopen sets.[23]
words.name: Zero-dimensional
